meanings.definition: A person who is old-fashioned or conservative in their views or behavior.
meanings.sent1: My grandpa is such a fuddy, always wearing his old hat and talking about the good old days.
meanings.sent2: The town was full of fuddies who preferred handwritten letters over emails.
meanings.sent3: The fuddy at the antique shop refused to sell me the vintage record player because he thought I was too young to appreciate it.
meanings.sent4: She was a fuddy in a world of fast-paced technology, like a vinyl record in a sea of streaming services.
meanings.sent5: The fuddy's house was like a time capsule, filled with old photographs and classic furniture.

meanings.definition: To make something old-fashioned or out of date.
meanings.sent1: She tried to fuddy her outfit by adding a retro scarf and vintage brooch.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to fuddy their logo to appeal to a more nostalgic audience.
meanings.sent3: He accidentally fuddied his phone when he dropped it in the puddle, making it look like a relic from the past.
meanings.sent4: The new technology quickly fuddied the old model, rendering it obsolete in a matter of months.
meanings.sent5: The artist intentionally fuddied her paintings by using traditional techniques in a modern art gallery.

meanings.definition: To act in a fussy or overprotective manner.
meanings.sent1: She would always fuddy over her plants, making sure they had just the right amount of sunlight and water.
meanings.sent2: The mother couldn't help but fuddy over her newborn baby, constantly checking if he was warm enough.
meanings.sent3: The chef would fuddy over every dish that left the kitchen, ensuring it was perfect down to the last garnish.
meanings.sent4: The coach would fuddy over his players, making sure they followed every training regimen to the letter.
meanings.sent5: The teacher would fuddy over the students during the field trip, counting heads every few minutes to make sure no one was lost.
